content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::AbstractString)
    q = ""
    a = ""

    lines = split(md, "\n")
    in_question = false
    in_answer = false

    for line in lines
        if startswith(line, "# Question")
            in_question = true
            q = strip(line[length("# Question"):end])
        elseif in_question && !startswith(line, "# Answer")
            q = q * " " * strip(line)
        elseif startswith(line, "# Answer")
            in_question = false
            in_answer = true
            a = strip(line[length("# Answer"):end])
        elseif in_answer && !startswith(line, "# Question")
            a = a * " " * strip(line)
        end
    end

    return (q, a)
end
```

This function `q_and_a_extractor(md::AbstractString)` takes a markdown-formatted text `md` and returns a tuple of two strings, where the first string is the question and the second string is the answer. It iterates through the lines of the input markdown text, distinguishing between sections titled "Question" and "Answer". The function removes any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.
